sentence: ? NC-11: Far-right freshman Rep. title: Madison Cawthorn vows to keep talking about Republican cocaine use and orgies

sentence: Sen. Thom Tillis announced Wednesday that he was endorsing state Sen. Chuck Edwards' campaign to defeat freshman Rep. Madison Cawthorn in the May 17 Republican primary for North Carolina's 11th District, saying the next day that the incumbent has fallen well short of the most basic standards Western North Carolina expects from their representatives.? Tillis threw in an unsubtle reference to Cawthorn's previous attempt to leave his constituents behind to run for an even more conservative district in the Charlotte area that he barely represented before a new court-drawn map foreclosed that possibility, antics that likely did him far more damage at home than his litany of embarrassing behavior.
title: North Carolina senator endorses effort to deny renomination to Madison Cawthorn in May

sentence: Co-hosts David Nir and David Beard also recap elections this week in California and Wisconsin; explain why Republicans are finally turning on Madison Cawthorn (it's not really about cocaine and orgies); pick apart a huge blunder that led the first attack ad in Pennsylvania's Democratic primary for Senate getting yanked off the air the very day it debuted; and provide updates on international elections in Hungary and France.
title: The Downballot: How Democrats are fighting to hold the House (transcript)

sentence: ? NC-11: Axios reports that Results for North Carolina, a super PAC close to Sen. Thom Tillis, is spending $310,000 on an ad campaign against Rep. Madison Cawthorn, which makes this the first major outside spending of the May 17 Republican primary.
